Math_Problem: Farmer Bill's 1000 animals - ducks, cows, and rabbits - are standing in a circle. In order to feel safe, every duck must either be standing next to at least one cow or between two rabbits. If there are 600 ducks, what is the least number of cows there can be for this to be possible? Instead of determining the minimal number of cows required, simply find $k = r - 198$, where $r$ is the number of rabbits in the arrangement that achieves this minimum. Find the largest integer $n$ such that the following holds: there exists a set of $n$ points in the plane such that, for any choice of $(k + 2)$ of them, some $(k + 1)$ are distance $k$ apart.

Connecting_Sentence.A1092: Instead of determining the minimal number of cows required, simply find $k = r - 198$, where $r$ is the number of rabbits in the arrangement that achieves this minimum.

Instead of determining the minimal number of cows required, simply find $k = r - 198$, where $r$ is the number of rabbits in the arrangement that achieves this minimum.

Synthesised_By.A1767: Find the largest integer $n$ such that the following holds: there exists a set of $n$ points in the plane such that, for any choice of three of them, some two are unit distance apart.

Original_Problem.A1092: Farmer Bill's 1000 animals - ducks, cows, and rabbits - are standing in a circle. In order to feel safe, every duck must either be standing next to at least one cow or between two rabbits. If there are 600 ducks, what is the least number of cows there can be for this to be possible?

Original_Problem.A1767: Find the largest integer $n$ such that the following holds: there exists a set of $n$ points in the plane such that, for any choice of three of them, some two are unit distance apart.

Claims.expr: minimal c ∈ ℕ s.t. ∃ circular arrangement of 600 ducks, c cows, (400 - c) rabbits where ∀ ducks: adjacent to ≥1 cow ∨ between 2 rabbits
|D_r| = r ⇒ alternating R D circle, total = 2r
max n : ∃ S ⊂ ℝ², |S|=n, ∀ {x,y,z} ⊂ S (dist(x,y)=1 ∨ dist(x,z)=1 ∨ dist(y,z)=1)
∃ S ⊂ ℝ², |S|=7 satisfying ∀ {x,y,z} ⊂ S (dist(x,y)=1 ∨ dist(x,z)=1 ∨ dist(y,z)=1)
¬ ∃ S ⊂ ℝ², |S|=8 satisfying ∀ {x,y,z} ⊂ S (dist(x,y)=1 ∨ dist(x,z)=1 ∨ dist(y,z)=1)
Assume ∃ S ⊂ ℝ², |S|=8 satisfying property, let G be unit dist graph on S, then α(G) ≤ 2
If deg_G(v) ≤ 3 for some v, contradiction
If deg_G(v) ≤ 3, then |U| ≥ 4 where U = V(G) \ ({v} ∪ N_G(v))
For α(G) ≤ 2, G[U] must be complete graph
If deg_G(v) ≥ 5 for some v, contradiction
If deg_G(v) ≥ 5, N_G(v) lies on unit circle centered at v
Unit dist graph H = G[N_G(v)] on 5 pts on unit circle has α(H) ≥ 3
6 non-isomorphic 3-regular graphs on 8 vertices; 5 have triangles, remaining has α = 4
No 3-regular triangle-free graph on 8 vertices with α ≤ 3
max n : ∃ S ⊂ ℝ², |S|=n, ∀ {x,y,z} ⊂ S (dist(x,y)=(r - 198) ∨ dist(x,z)=(r - 198) ∨ dist(y,z)=(r - 198))
